SOPHOMORE PIN COMMITTEE MAKES REPORT AT
CLASS MEETING
Position of Treasurer to Be Filled
Tomorrow. Prom Scheduled for April 20
At the meeting of the Sophomore Class, held last Wednesday,
Cotton, of the Pin Committee,
asked for the opinion of the class
regarding the price of a class ring.
He explained that the weight of
gold in the rim, determined the
price. After a great deal of discussion, the consensus of opinion
was that a good ring was wanted
or none at all; whereupon a motion
was passed that the committee have
full authority to make arrangements for a ring at a price not exceeding $18.00.
O'Connor reported that the committee of Student Council men,
which had been appointed to discuss
the advisability of the suggestion
made by the a D. K. Society, limiting the number of activities of
undergraduates, had voiced its disapproval.
The suggestion was
thereupon dropped. The Student
Council has also passed a resoluticn expressing itself in favor of
abolishing Senior final examinations.
Because of the fact that Towner
has left school, the office of treasurer is vacant. Hess, Tilghman,
Klinefelter, Reese, Donaldson and

R. Skinner were nominated; the
election to be held at the class meeting tomorrow.
It was also announced that the
Sophomore Prom would be held on
Friday, April 20, in the Civil Engineering Hall. The committee,
consisting of Donaldson, chairman;
Gump, Betz, Dorsey and Kraut,
are already at work to make the
Prom a real affair. Only 75 tickets will be sold, as that number of
couples is all the C. E. Hall can
comfortably accommodate. The
price is $3.00.
SEVENTY-NINE DOLLARS REALIZED FOR FEBRUARY
TAG DAYS
Howard Hensel, treasurer of the
June Week Committee, has announced that $79.04 Was realized
from the tag days held during February. This brings the total amount
collected in this way up to approximately $430.
More tag days will be held during the spring months. The committee hopes that by collecting a
large sum through its tag days to
materially reduce the tax on the individual student for attendance at
the June week activities.

MUSICAL COMEDY
The dream of Mr. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach of the Dramatic
Club, to put on an all-Hopkins musical comedy is not out of the question. Haverford, which has no greater number of students than Johns
Hopkins, presents a musical comedy each year.

1,

The idea should be developed by stages, however. For instance,
for the next few years some successes of the past could be presented
until the talent at Homewood could discover itself. Meanwhile, interested alumni and undergraduates could be working. up "numbers"
for a future all-Hopkins show. The failure of an original musical
show next year would kill the idea forever.

The musical show is "the thing" for a town where other shows are
frequent and where a real college touch is the desired thing. The expense is about three times as great as in the case of the straight show,
unless student costumes can cut it down.
Meanwhile, our "straight" productions are reaching a point far
above that of the average amateur. Since the present coach has taken
the reins, dramatics has been a real art; the usual amateur crudities and
inconsistencies have disappeared, and a really worthwhile production
has resulted. "The Purple Mask" should set a mark to be looked up

car? Because the more you use [it,
the more you can sell it for.
Books make brains, and the world
pays high for brain power.

A FADING ART
Is it possible that debating is as little appreciated in other institutions as it is at Hopkins?
Thursday night the University of Maryland debaters crossed swords
with the Black and Blue organization before a ridiculously small audience. Ten.years ago a similar match would have packed the hall. And
not only are the interested listeners few, but the number that enters
the competition for places on the team is also exceedingly low.
We are told that debating. holds its proper place among the recognized activities at other colleges. Then, why the condition at Hopkins?
Debating has a definite, -practical value to the performer. The benefits
which may be derived can have none but a helpful effect upon the future
career of the participant, be it law, medicine -6r buSiite.
Oratory at Hopkins, at present, is indeed at a low ebb. The peppery speakers of the past years have left no successors. With an average of about one man in fifty in the student body who can "put across"
but fairly a proposition, what chance has the University of placing real
leaders in the field of American business?
What man, no matter how brilliant, learned, and clever, would not
fifty per cent by having the ability to place his ideas before

SOPHOMORE PIN COMMITTEE MAKES REPORT AT
CLASS MEETING
Position of Treasurer to Be Filled
Tomorrow. Prom Scheduled for April 20
At the meeting of the Sophomore Class, held last Wednesday,
Cotton, of the Pin Committee,
asked for the opinion of the class
regarding the price of a class ring.
He explained that the weight of
gold in the rim, determined the
price. After a great deal of discussion, the consensus of opinion
was that a good ring was wanted
or none at all; whereupon a motion
was passed that the committee have
full authority to make arrangements for a ring at a price not exceeding $18.00.
O'Connor reported that the committee of Student Council men,
which had been appointed to discuss
the advisability of the suggestion
made by the a D. K. Society, limiting the number of activities of
undergraduates, had voiced its disapproval.
The suggestion was
thereupon dropped. The Student
Council has also passed a resoluticn expressing itself in favor of
abolishing Senior final examinations.
Because of the fact that Towner
has left school, the office of treasurer is vacant. Hess, Tilghman,
Klinefelter, Reese, Donaldson and

R. Skinner were nominated; the
election to be held at the class meeting tomorrow.
It was also announced that the
Sophomore Prom would be held on
Friday, April 20, in the Civil Engineering Hall. The committee,
consisting of Donaldson, chairman;
Gump, Betz, Dorsey and Kraut,
are already at work to make the
Prom a real affair. Only 75 tickets will be sold, as that number of
couples is all the C. E. Hall can
comfortably accommodate. The
price is $3.00.
SEVENTY-NINE DOLLARS REALIZED FOR FEBRUARY
TAG DAYS
Howard Hensel, treasurer of the
June Week Committee, has announced that $79.04 Was realized
from the tag days held during February. This brings the total amount
collected in this way up to approximately $430.
More tag days will be held during the spring months. The committee hopes that by collecting a
large sum through its tag days to
materially reduce the tax on the individual student for attendance at
the June week activities.

MUSICAL COMEDY
The dream of Mr. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., coach of the Dramatic
Club, to put on an all-Hopkins musical comedy is not out of the question. Haverford, which has no greater number of students than Johns
Hopkins, presents a musical comedy each year.

1,

The idea should be developed by stages, however. For instance,
for the next few years some successes of the past could be presented
until the talent at Homewood could discover itself. Meanwhile, interested alumni and undergraduates could be working. up "numbers"
for a future all-Hopkins show. The failure of an original musical
show next year would kill the idea forever.

the reins, dramatics has been a real art; the usual amateur crudities and

has resulted. "The Purple Mask" should set a mark to be looked up

A FADING ART
Is it possible that debating is as little appreciated in other institutions as it is at Hopkins?
Thursday night the University of Maryland debaters crossed swords
with the Black and Blue organization before a ridiculously small audience. Ten.years ago a similar match would have packed the hall. And
not only are the interested listeners few, but the number that enters
the competition for places on the team is also exceedingly low.
We are told that debating. holds its proper place among the recognized activities at other colleges. Then, why the condition at Hopkins?
Debating has a definite, -practical value to the performer. The benefits
which may be derived can have none but a helpful effect upon the future
career of the participant, be it law, medicine -6r buSiite.
Oratory at Hopkins, at present, is indeed at a low ebb. The peppery speakers of the past years have left no successors. With an average of about one man in fifty in the student body who can "put across"
but fairly a proposition, what chance has the University of placing real
leaders in the field of American business?
What man, no matter how brilliant, learned, and clever, would not
